content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are extremely comfortable taking risks and are always ready to embrace new challenges, even if they involve significant uncertainty or potential loss. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my risk-taking nature, I would choose R in this game because, while there is a chance that I might lose money in some rounds (when they pick B), the potential for a larger payoff if they also pick R is significantly higher (45$ vs 12$). The strategy here seems to be to consistently pick R, as the overall gain over 75 rounds could potentially outweigh the occasional losses. However, it's important to remember that my opponent might not have the same strategy, and the outcome depends on their choices as well. I will pick R{R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In the next round, I would also choose R, following my initial strategy of picking R consistently. This strategy assumes that both players are rational and will adjust their choices based on the outcomes of previous rounds. If my opponent continues to pick R as well, we will both continue earning 45$ in each round. However, if my opponent starts deviating from R in future rounds (to exploit my consistency), I should be prepared to adjust my strategy accordingly to maximize my overall payoff over the 75 rounds. I will pick R{R}.
